topic_metadata.title: How to pass formatted markup to a string argument?

posts.name: St. Elmo Wilken
posts.cooked: When a package expects a string argument, what is the easiest way to supply it with a string that has e.g. italics in it? Entering [blah _blah_ blah] does not work, since this is content instead of a string…
posts.raw: When a package expects a string argument, what is the easiest way to supply it with a string that has e.g. italics in it? Entering `[blah _blah_ blah]` does not work, since this is content instead of a string...

posts.name: Baryhobal
posts.cooked:
What exactly do you mean by “a string that has italics in it” ?
Do you mean like "blah _blah_ blah" ? In which case it is simply a string, the underscores only have a special meaning in content or math mode
posts.raw:

posts.name: St. Elmo Wilken
posts.cooked: So I suppose I am asking, is there a way to format a string to have italics? I.e. is there some string formatting escape command that converts “blah blah” into “blah blah”?
posts.raw: So I suppose I am asking, is there a way to format a string to have italics? I.e. is there some string formatting escape command that converts "blah _blah_" into "blah *blah*"?

posts.name: jimpjorps
posts.cooked:
You can eval a string as markup:

#let food-review = "now _that's_ a spicy meatball"
#eval(food-review, mode: "markup")

However, if the package is expecting a string as an input and then doing string operations on it, then there’s not much you can do; you’d have to change the function yourself to accept content.
posts.raw:
You can `eval` a string as markup:

```typ
#let food-review = "now _that's_ a spicy meatball"
#eval(food-review, mode: "markup")
```

However, if the package is expecting a string as an input and then doing string operations on it, then there's not much you can do; you'd have to change the function yourself to accept content.
